_accidents.ED_Other: DAMAGE DONE TO SOYBEAN CROP IN FIELD NEXT TO THIS LOCATION
_accidents.CF_Other: TAMPERING WITH ANHYDROUS TANK IN AN APPARENT ATTEMPTED THEFT OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA
_accidents.CI_OtherType: MORE PATROLS MADE BY EMPLOYEES AND THE LOCAL POLICE DEPARTMENT TO MONITOR TAMPERING WITH ANHYDROUS EQUIPMENT

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Facility accidental release and emergency response policy. The management and employees of Effingham Clay Service Company are committed to prevention of accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. If any accidental release should occur. The facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Local Emergency planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.
2.    The stationary source and the regulated substances handled. The primary activity at the facility which is located at 310 West North Water Street, Bethany  Illinois is the storage and blending of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling systems consists of one ? 30,000gallon and one 18.000gallon storage tanks, loading risers, and associated plumbing and nurse tanks.
3.    The accidental release prevention program. This facility complies withy EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of ?Safety requirements for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, K-61.1, published by the American National Standards Institute Inc.  As adopted by State regulations and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). 29 CFR 1910.111, ?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia?. Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.
4.    Five year accident history. We had an accidental release of 370 pounds of anhydrous ammonia on 08/03/2002 at our facility as a result of someone tampering with our anhydrous wagon. There was no one injured or effected by the release of anhydrous ammonia. There was no environmental damage done by the release. There was approx. $300 worth of property ( one acre of soybeans in adjoining fi

eld) effected by this release.
5.    The Emergency Response Program. The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29CFR 1910.38 and have provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)
6.    Planned changes to improve safety. Safety improvement is an on going process at the facility, Periodic evaluations are performed to access the maintenance of safe conditions, There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
